entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid. You are also considered a goblinoid for any prerequisite or effect that requires you to be a goblinoid.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Goblin.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

entries.name: Fey Ancestry
entries: You have advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the {@condition charmed} condition on yourself.

entries.name: Opportunistic Hunter
entries: The Tak'Garun have a long and storied history of being accomplished hunters. Once per turn, when you make an attack roll at advantage, you deal an additional {@damage 1d6} damage.

entries.name: Long-Limbed
entries: When you make a melee attack on your turn, your reach for it is 5 feet greater than normal.

entries.name: Powerful Build
entries: You count as one size larger when determining your carrying capacity and the weight you can push, drag, or lift.

entries.name: Hidden Harrier
entries: You are proficient in the {@skill Stealth} skill. Additionally, when you use the Help Action on an ally towards an attack, your range to do so is 30 feet, and that ally has advantage on all attack rolls until the end of their next turn. This trait can only be used once per combat encounter.

entries.name: Springborn
entries: You have spent enough time in the magical hot springs to channel their calming power. You can cast the {@spell sanctuary} and {@spell calm emotions} spells with this trait, without expending a spell slot. Once you cast either of these spells with this trait, you can't cast that spell with it again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast these using spell slots you have of the appropriate level.
Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma is your spellcasting ability for these spells when cast with this trait (choose when you select this race).

Bugbears, known as Tak’Garun in their homeland of Arovatan, are a serene and disciplined people, grounded in the relentless pursuit of personal and communal excellence. Central to Tak’Garun philosophy is a steadfast commitment to tranquility and unwavering focus.

entries.name: Age
entries: Tak'Garun reach adulthood at 16 and live up to 80.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Tak'Garun tend to be Lawful by culture. The structure of their communities prioritize the prefection of nurtured talent in service of the group as a whole.

entries.name: Martial Prowess
entries: Tak’Garun society reveres martial prowess as a means of achieving harmony and balance within oneself. Instead of brute force, they seek mastery of their minds and bodies through rigorous training in martial arts and combat techniques. Every Bugbear strives to achieve a state of inner tranquility and fluidity in movement, embodying the ideals of discipline and self-control.

entries.name: Harmony with Nature
entries: In harmony with their environment, Tak’Garun Bugbears hold a profound reverence for nature and its intricacy. Preferring secluded regions amidst dense forests and serene mountains, they establish settlements where they tend to lush gardens, and engage in meditative practices. These communities seamlessly integrate with the natural world, embodying their profound bond with the earth.

entries.name: Duty
entries: Within Tak’Garun culture, family and community hold utmost importance. Led by respected elders who embody wisdom, compassion, and duty, Bugbear clans prioritize loyalty and unity. Tak’Garun individuals staunchly defend and uphold their kin, ready to undertake any endeavor to safeguard their families and provide support. Committed to fulfilling their responsibilities, they stand ready to defend their homeland and extend aid to those in need, reflecting their unwavering dedication to their community.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light and in darkness as if it were dim light. You discern colors in that darkness only as shades of gray.

entries.name: Bite
entries: Gnolls have powerful jaws thhat they ofoten incorporate in the way they fight. You can use your bite as a natural weapon with the finesse property. When you hit with it, you deal {@damage 1d6} + your Strength or Dexterity modifer piercing damage.

entries.name: A Good Heckling
entries: Gnolls learn to distract and disorient their opponents by taunting. You know the {@spell vicious mockery} cantrip, and your spellcasting ability is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma when cast with this trait (choose when you select this race).

entries.name: Bolstering Cackle
entries: Gnolls approach combat with a glee that is infectious. Once per combat encounter, you can use a bonus action to a give a number of creatures euqla to your proficiency bonus temporary hit points equal to 4 times your proficiency bonus.

entries.name: Rampage
entries: When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with a melee attack on your turn, you can immediately use your bonus action to move up to half your speed and make an attack with your Bite. You can use this trait a number of times equal to your proficiency bonus, and regain all expended uses after a long rest.

Altoran Gnolls commonly worship the Wolf, the Lovers, and the Shepherd. They value their freedom and tend to travel in close knit matriarchal clans. They are commonly found in the forests and plains of Cennvarai and Muhanna, though sometimes they’ve been known to organize flotillas to near by islands if resources are scarce. In very rare cases they are known to even engage in piracy. Gnolls are generally disliked in the cities as they often raid trade caravans that travel through their territory. Some Gnolls will leave their clans to become adventurers or strike their own paths.

entries.name: Age
entries: Gnolls mature to adulthood after 18 years. They can live to 200 years of age, but this is rarely the case outside of the Matriarch of the clan. The life of a Gnoll is often times violent and swift.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Gnolls tend to be chaotic by culture. The structure of their clans are fluid and tend to have those deemd to be 'strong of mind, body, or will' taking positions of leadership. A Matriarch is expected to be a mature member of the clan that is the strongest in all of these qualities, and will defend this position if the need arises.

entries.name: Strength
entries: Gnoll Matriarchs are both the most powerful warrior and the wisest of the clan. However, to the Gnolls, strength is less about physical prowess and more the pursuit of excellence in one's capabilities.

entries.name: Family
entries: Gnoll clans are combinations of several extended families, but the bonds between these families are as strong as kin. Gnolls who leave their packs will join mercenary troupes or adventuring parties. They are staunch allies and will put their life on the line for their chosen family.

entries.name: Fun
entries: Gnolls love to laugh and horse around with their friends and family, creating a very animate space wherever they may settle. Part of the Matriarch's duty is to wrangle and focus the will of her pack. Gnolls that have struck out on their own can be found participating in raucous parties or wandering into different festivals. Even in the heat of combat, a Gnoll might find something to cackle about. Life is to be enjoyed even in the toughest of situations.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and Grung.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: You can breathe both air and water.

entries.name: Poison Resistance
entries: You have resistance to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws you make to avoid or end the poisoned condition on yourself.

entries.name: Poisonous Skin
entries: As a free action on your turn, you can choose to secrete poison from your skin. Until the start of your next turn, any creature that grapples you or otherwise comes into direct contact with your skin must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or become poisoned for 1 minute. Once the poisoned creature is no longer in direct contact with you, it can repeat the saving throw at the end of each of its turns, ending the condition on a success.

Alternatively, you can choose to apply your poison to a weapon when you make an attack. On hit, the target must succeed on a DC 15 Constitution saving throw or take an additional {@damage 2d4} poison damage.
This trait can only be used once per comabt encounter.

entries.name: Standing Leap
entries: Your long jump is up to 30 feet, and your high jump is up to 15 feet, with or without a running start.

There are quite a few different frog-like humanoids or monsters you could encounter out in the swamps, but how many of them are brightly colored and ready to give you some strange poisons that can cause all sorts of odd reactions, like sudden death? While some may confuse the Grung for other creatures, like bullywugs and grippli, Grung resemble small humanoids with strong  toad or frog-like legs that end in webbed feet, making them capable of long leaps without extensive training.

entries.name: Age
entries: Grung mature to adulthood in a single year, but have been known to live up to 100 years.

entries.name: Alignment
entries: Most Grung are lawful, having been raised in a strict caste system. They tend towards evil as well, coming from a culture where social advancement occurs rarely, and most often because another member of your army has died.

entries.name: Abilities
entries: Grung continuously secrete a light poisonous substance that is harmless to them (despite not being immune to other poisons and venoms). This secretion is quite sticky, and Grungs can concentrate to produce a highly toxic substance that they can apply to any weapon. When exposed to air, Grung poison quickly deteriorates and breaks down within a minute, making it extremely hard to harvest and bottle. Their saliva contains the same but weakened poison.

entries.name: Amphibious
entries: Grungs are amphibious, but although they could survive underwater, they were better climbers than swimmers, moreso needing to submerge themselves in water for comfort from lack of dry skin rather than being natural swimmers.

entries.name: Behaviour
entries: Due to their size, Grung often avoided direct confrontation and preferred ambushing their prey. The most common ambush strategy was laying camouflaged and waiting for their opponents, Grung from other tribes, or quarry to venture into the range of their short bows or throwing spears. If their prey survived the initially volley of poisoned weapons, the Grung would flee across the tree tops so as not to leave any trail.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: You are proficient in the Perception skill, and you have advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sound or smell.

entries.name: Cornered Fury
entries: While your hit points are at or below a number equal to twice your level, you have advantage on all melee attacks.

entries.name: Gnashing Incisors
entries: You have a powerful bite that can gnaw through flesh and steel. Your bite is a natural weapon, which counts as a simple melee weapon with the finesse property with which you are proficient. On a hit, the bite deals {@damage 1d8} + your Strength or Dexterity modifier piercing damage. This damage is doubled against objects and structures.

entries.name: Impeccable Balance
entries: You have advantage on saves and ability checks to avoid being knocked prone.

To the people at large, Ratfolk have the most difficulty with life in Altoras. They are deft of foot and are sometimes drawn to a criminal lifestyle, particularly those born in the city of New Burrow, forced to choose between living in the underground city ruled by the mob or on the Kaiju infested jungles above. Though this is the unfortunate situation for most Ratfolk, they are no more naturally violent or larcenous than others, but old stereotypes linger, especially with the affluant of New Burrow actively putting their interests above all else.

entries.name: Age
entries: Ratfolk mature at age 12 and live up to 80 years.

entries.name: Determined Survivalist
entries: Curiosity, ingenuity and survival; these three concepts drove the ratfolk to where they are today. Seemingly ever-present in the nooks and crannies of civilization. Ratfolk are affable even though their large ratlike appearance may be offputting to some.

entries.name: Society
entries: Ratfolk society is similar to what one would expect in a more honorable thieves’ guild; Pickpocket from those who have more than they need, never steal from another from the group (unless they’re asking for it) and never travel without an accomplice. These three unwritten rules have allowed most Ratfolk societies to prosper, at least for those who embrace the easy path. Many brave Ratfolk eschew this way of life and strike out on their own in the dangerous world, looking for likeminded folk who focus on things besides their own selfish needs.

entries.name: A Place in the World
entries: A Ratfolk adventurer is one who seeks a place in a world where acceptance and acknowledgement for their kind doesn’t come easily. Though Ratfolk are cautious, they are neither fearful nor stupid, and the opportunity to face enemies and beat traps give Ratfolk a sense of challenge. For Ratfolk, the chance to complete a task no one else can give them, the best chance to earn their keep with a group, if not the world. Ratfolk dislike the norms placed on them, but while they don’t seek to affect such change in attitude on a large scale, they place great value on the opinions of those few they come to trust. This trust comes with much time and effort, and can be lost easily if abused.

entries.name: Creature Type
entries: You are a Humanoid.

entries.name: Languages
entries: You can speak, read, and write Common and one other language of your choice.

entries.name: Storm Born
entries: You have resistance to lightning damage.

entries.name: Storm Serpent's Boon
entries: You know the {@spell lightning lure} and {@spell shocking grasp} cantrips. Starting at 3rd level, you can cast the {@spell invisibility} with this trait without expending a spell slot. Once cast in this way, you cannot cast it in this way again until you finish a long rest. You can also cast this spell using spell slots you have of the appopriate level.
Your spellcasting ability for these spells is Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma (choose when you select this race).

The Yuan-ti of Altoras can be found deep in the jungles of Muhana and Jagara. They were said to be once humans struggling to survive in the hostile jungles. In their histories they tell tales of a ritual that imbued them with the power of a great sky serpent. A leviathan said to roam the skies, never seen, but felt in the savagery of the storms that ride its wake. They are a secretive people, that entertain few visitors. They are said to live in cities hidden in the jungle ruled by clerics of this great serpent and The Shepherd.

entries.name: Age
entries: Yuan-ti mature at the same rate as humans do, but live slightly longer to an average of 150 years. After the age of 40, it becomes difficult to determine how old one might be as they retain their youthful appearance.

entries.name: Privacy
entries: Yuan-ti society values their traditions and are wary of those who come to them. They are a private and self reflective people, preferring to keep matters to those directly involved or affected by them. This can lead outsiders to think of them as cold and difficult to connect with.

entries.name: Stoicism
entries: The Yuan-ti believe in the sanctity of nature, and this belief and respect for the cycles of nature have led to an acceptance of circumstances they can’t control. They value self control and focus their attention to finding the things that are within their power. To the Yuan-ti the world is full of things beyond their ken; survival comes from grasping what can be understood and worked with.

entries.name: Resilience
entries: Through the guidance of The Shepherd and the unity of the clan the Yuan-ti believe they can survive the harshness of the world around them. They draw strength from the world around them and the histories of their people. With the storm in their veins they are masters of their deep jungle homes. A Yuan-ti is expected to be able to draw strength from within and the clan when faced with difficulty from both without and within.
